dublin_core.dcvalue: The World Health Organization estimated that major depression is the fourth most significant cause of disability worldwide for people aged 65 and older where depressed older adults reported decreased independence poor health poor quality of life functional decline disability and increased chronic medical problems Therefore the objectives of this study were 1 to develop a low cost point of care testing system for psychomotor symptoms of depression and 2 to evaluate the system in community dwelling elderly in India The preliminary results from the cross sectional study showed a significant negative linear correlation between balance and depression Here monitoring quantitative electroencephalography along with the center of pressure for cued response time during functional reach tasks may provide insights into the psychomotor symptoms of depression where average slope of the Theta Alpha power ratio versus average slope of baseline normalized response time may be a candidate biomarker which remains to be evaluated in our future clinical studies Once validated the biomarker can be used for monitoring the outcome of a comprehensive therapy program in conjunction with pharmacological interventions Furthermore the frequency of falls can be monitored with a mobile phone based application where the propensity of falls during the periods of psychomotor symptoms of depression can be investigated further
